#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Become a Veterinary Anatomist
#Text=Veterinary anatomy is a specialized field of veterinary science that studies the biological structure and the different systems that make up an animal 's body .
#Text=Veterinary anatomists can apply their skills by helping animals at a veterinary clinic , or by advancing the field of veterinary medicine in a laboratory .

#Text=Preparing for a career in veterinary anatomy can be a long process ; study science and veterinary medicine , work with animals , meet other veterinary anatomists , and you 'll be able to start your career in the field of veterinary anatomy .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Studying to be a Veterinary Anatomist
#Text=Study science and math in high school .
#Text=You can start preparing for a career as a veterinary anatomist in high school .
#Text=Taking classes in biology , anatomy , and chemistry is a great way to prepare for a career in the veterinary field .
#Text=Math and statistics classes will also be very helpful if you want to do veterinary research .
#Text=Take pre-requisite classes as an undergraduate student .
#Text=Veterinary anatomists , like all veterinarians , must go through many years of education before they can be licensed to practice medicine or perform research in a lab .
#Text=Take math , biology , chemistry , and anatomy classes while completing a bachelor 's degree to fulfill the prerequisite requirements for enrolling in veterinary medical schools .
#Text=Some colleges offer pre-veterinary tracks for undergraduate students .
#Text=Enrolling in a school with a pre-veterinary track will help you make sure that you take all of the pre-requisite classes .
#Text=Majoring in biology , chemistry , or anatomy can be helpful , but it is not required for attending veterinary school .
#Text=Specialize in veterinary science for your master 's degree .
#Text=Some veterinary schools require students to have a master 's degree before enrolling to get their doctoral degree .

#Text=A master 's degree might not be necessary for the school you want to attend , but earning a Master 's in Veterinary Science will give you plenty of helpful knowledge and experience for your future as a veterinary anatomist .
#Text=Enroll in an accredited school of veterinary medicine .
#Text=Earning a Doctorate of Veterinary Medicine is the last step in a veterinarian 's education .

#Text=Research accredited universities , learn about the funding and financial aid those schools provide , understand their academic requirements , and learn about the faculty members who teach at that school .
#Text=Apply to schools that employ well-known veterinary anatomists to have the opportunity to learn from them .
#Text=Unlike medical schools , it is unusual for schools of veterinary medicine to offer formal tracks or specialties to students .
#Text=Some schools offer dual Ph. D. /DVM programs where students graduate with a DVM and Ph.D. in a related veterinary science .
#Text=Having a Ph.D. in addition to your DVM will provide you with a great background for a career in veterinary research .
#Text=Earn your license to practice as a veterinarian .
#Text=After you graduate , you must meet licensing and certification requirements in order to practice as a veterinarian .
#Text=Each state has its own rules and regulations .
#Text=File the appropriate paperwork and take any required exams , and soon you can enter the veterinary workforce .
#Text=Developing the Skills to Be a Veterinary Anatomist
#Text=Find opportunities to work with animals .
#Text=Volunteer with local animal shelters , zoos , and veterinary clinics , or find a job at a local pet store .
#Text=Earning experience with animals of all shapes and sizes will help you decide if you would like to work with animals in a clinical setting , or if you would prefer to do research .
#Text=Colleges and veterinary schools both appreciate candidates who have volunteering experience .
#Text=Start volunteering as soon as possible , and continue volunteering through college and veterinary school if you find the time .
#Text=Complete an internship or externship with a veterinarian or with a laboratory .
#Text=Applying to do an internship or an externship is a great way to earn first-hand experience in a veterinarian 's office or a laboratory .
#Text=Many students get their first opportunity to work in a professional setting through an internship or externship , and they are a great way to get to know people who work in your chosen field .
#Text=Continue your education in veterinary anatomy .
#Text=Veterinary anatomy is an emergent field .
#Text=To succeed in it , you will need to know the latest developments in veterinary science .
#Text=Attend conferences , read research journals , and talk with other veterinary anatomists to learn more about your field .
#Text=The American Veterinary Medical Associations requires all members to participate in a continuing education program .
#Text=Take advantage of continuing education classes that can teach you more about veterinary anatomy .
#Text=Finding a Job as a Veterinary Anatomist
#Text=Create a professional and distinctive resume .
#Text=While you search for a job as a veterinary anatomist , make yourself stand out from your peers .
#Text=Create a strong , professional resume that clearly displays your education and describes your previous work experience .
#Text=Include your experience working with other scientists and veterinarians as well as your experience working with animals .
#Text=Network with other veterinary anatomists .
#Text=Meeting other veterinary anatomists is a great way to learn more about your field , share information , and make professional contacts .
#Text=Join the American or the World Association of Veterinary Anatomists .
#Text=These groups host conferences , share exciting scientific developments in veterinary anatomy and provide information about job openings to their members .
#Text=Join online discussion groups and veterinary forums to meet and communicate with other veterinary anatomists .
#Text=Search for open positions at laboratories , universities , and with private companies .
#Text=Veterinary anatomy is a specialized field , and you may struggle to find open positions through a general job-searching website .
#Text=Be specific in your job search by look for open positions at veterinarian 's offices and at places that perform research that benefits animals .
#Text=You can find jobs openings through the American Medical Veterinary Association .

#Text=If you have specialized in veterinary anatomy research , look for openings with research universities , or with private companies that specialize in creating products like medicine , food , or toys for animals .
#Text=If you would like to teach veterinary anatomy to others , search for open positions at schools of veterinary medicine .
#Text=Prepare to talk about your experience with veterinary anatomy during job interviews .
#Text=Be prepared to talk about your previous experience and education with the people who are conducting your interview .
#Text=Expect to explain why you decided to study veterinary anatomy , the subjects you researched while in school , and your previous experience working with animals .
#Text=Be prepared to explain the work experience and educational opportunities that you included on your resume .
#Text=Practice answering these questions before your interview to develop well-rounded , honest answers and to calm your pre-interview jitters .
